turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: You... you say that a truck doesn't have a going-concern value, but that really wasn't what was at issue here, was it?
It was a truck by an owner who had a long-term contractual relationship with... what, was it Lane, the... the... the--

turn.speaker: john_j_durkay
turn.label: Mr. John J. Durkay
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --the trucking concern.
So that we... we have something more than a truck here.
And why, therefore, isn't it fair, even on your premise, to say there... there would be a going-concern value here?

turn.speaker: john_j_durkay
turn.label: Mr. John J. Durkay
turn.text: He... he wasn't renting his truck on a long-term basis.
Every day he showed up and hauled, he got paid.
If he didn't, he didn't.
And a part of that activity--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Yeah, but I... I... I'm--

turn.speaker: john_j_durkay
turn.label: Mr. John J. Durkay
turn.text: --It wasn't--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --maybe... maybe I'm making an assumption, in fact, that is wrong, but I assume that if I were to go out in the market and buy a truck, and show up in Lane's driveway tomorrow morning, I would not get the same kind of preference for business that this individual would.

turn.speaker: john_j_durkay
turn.label: Mr. John J. Durkay
turn.text: --No, you would.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Okay.
So he's got something that I, as a buyer on the open market, wouldn't have, and therefore there at least is a sense in which--

turn.speaker: john_j_durkay
turn.label: Mr. John J. Durkay
turn.text: No.
You... you would get--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --there's a going concern.

turn.speaker: john_j_durkay
turn.label: Mr. John J. Durkay
turn.text: --You would get the Lane deal.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: john_j_durkay
turn.label: Mr. John J. Durkay
turn.text: You would get the Lane deal.
If you showed up at Lane, you would be able to haul for Lane on the same basis as Mr. Rash.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But Lane believes in equal protection no matter who shows up?

turn.speaker: john_j_durkay
turn.label: Mr. John J. Durkay
turn.text: If you can drive--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I can't even shift the truck, and he's going to give me the business?
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: john_j_durkay
turn.label: Mr. John J. Durkay
turn.text: --But, see, that's the point.
The value here is two components.
There's the truck and there's the truck driver.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Yeah.
And the truck driver is part of the deal.

turn.speaker: john_j_durkay
turn.label: Mr. John J. Durkay
turn.text: No, the truck driver wasn't pledged to the Associates.
[Laughter]
That's... that's a 13th amendment problem.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No, but the... the truck... the truck driver is the one who is going to use the truck if he retains it.
And that makes a difference, doesn't it, economically?

turn.speaker: john_j_durkay
turn.label: Mr. John J. Durkay
turn.text: I don't think it does.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Durkay.

turn.speaker: john_j_durkay
turn.label: Mr. John J. Durkay
turn.text: Thank you, sir.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Phillips, you have 3 minutes remaining.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice.
I'll try to be short or briefer than that.
I think, ultimately, the case could be disposed of based on, essentially, Justice Scalia's question, which is, you have language that says "proposed disposition or proposed use".
And we... every example he gave talked about auctions, talked about sales.
He's got lots of use for the language 506(a).
And... and, in fact, if you look in his brief, he doesn't offer up an explanation of what that language is designed to mean.
And the only brief on their side is the one amicus brief says that 12 proceeding.
And it's reasonably clear to me that, to have to stretch that far to find some meaning in this particular language, tells you that their interpretation really eliminates the "proposed use" term.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Of course, "proposed use" doesn't really lead you to "retail value" necessarily.
I mean I... I can see how it doesn't lead you to "wholesale value", but why does it lead you to "retail value"?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, what... what it leads you to, ultimately... and the value we're looking for and the rule we ask for is what it would cost the debtor to purchase the same property in the open market.
And that's the fair market value.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But why isn't that the same as the fair market value of this truck, as appraised?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Because the--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Or is it?
I'm not sure whether or not--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Well, it... it is.
It's the... I mean if he had to go out and buy this truck today, it would have cost him either 41,000 or--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --But why is that different from what it can be sold for if you have fair opportunity to offer it in the market?
Why is there... I... I must confess, I should have asked this in the very beginning... but why is the fair market diff... value... different, depending on whether you're the buyer or the seller?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Because of the differences of what you can get for it.
I mean I realize that's tautological, but I mean--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But you're saying there are two different markets.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Yes, exactly.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yeah.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: It's the market that... that determines it.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, I would have thought the difference might be what you have to pay somebody, by way of a commission, to sell it for you.
I mean if the debtor is going to keep it, it isn't going to be sold.
But if the creditor is going to take it back and sell it, they're going to have to pay something to somebody to do that, in effect--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: That's true.
And--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --typically.
And I thought that was the real difference.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Right.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Maybe I'm wrong.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: No, I think that's right.
And that... that plays out particularly in the hypothetical foreclosure cases, where you have a foreclosure on the house and you... and you--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yeah, but that... that assumption means if you keep the truck, you save the commission.
Yeah.
So that would be the cheaper value.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Well, except if... if you keep the truck, he wouldn't save the commission, because he... they would ask you to deduct the hypothetical cost of the commission.
And that's... and that... and there are some decisions to that effect.
But I... as... for reasons I think I've made clear, I think those decisions are wrong.
If there are no other questions, I would urge the Court to--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Phillips.
The case is submitted.
